en_results_raw: complete, and her tastes were by no means the same as his. She was a woman of mean understanding, little information, and uncertain temper. When she married Mr. Bennet, she thought herself very happy, and believed that she was making a great match. She had little regard for the sense and talents of her husband, which she openly slighted, but admired his large fortune, and that it was in the hands of a man of education, and who had a good estate. Mr. Bennet was so odd a mixture of quick parts, sarcastic humour, reserve, and caprice, that the experience of three-and-twenty years had been insufficient to make his wife understand his character. Her mind was less difficult to comprehend. She had always been accustomed to live in a sort of dissipation, which gave her a permanent inclination to more immediate enjoyment, and made her regard the business of her husband's estate as a troublesome innovation. She was fond of parade, and Mr. Bennet's plain manners offended her. She had little taste for reading, and no inclination to improve her mind by any effort of thought. To music she was somewhat partial, and often practised on the pianoforte. She was fond of fine clothes, and often regretted the absence of a park and a mansion. Her idea of elegance led her to admire paintings and china, but the real beauty of nature, or the solid grandeur of architecture, was quite beyond her comprehension. She was a woman of mean understanding, little information, and uncertain temper. When she married Mr. Bennet, she thought herself very happy, and believed that she was making a great match. She had little regard for the sense and talents of her husband, which she openly slighted, but admired his large fortune, and that it was in the hands of a man of education, and who had a good estate. Mr. Bennet, on his side, had little to admire in his wife when he first saw her, but he soon found reason to respect her understanding, and to love her person. Her manners were warm and lively; her mind affable and docile; and though not educated in the highest sphere, she had a natural taste for literature, and a disposition to improve. Her love of music was very real, and her voice, though not of the finest texture, was capable of great expression. She played with great spirit, and sang with more. Her person was neither delicate nor handsome, but she had a pleasant countenance, and a cheerful air which always made her appear amiable. Her disposition was chiefly in the good sense of the word; and though sometimes a little too ready to speak her mind, she had enough of wit to carry it well. Her affection for her husband was sincere, and her respect for his abilities was not affected. She never teased him, or tried to engage his attention by frivolous trifles. Her happiness was not dependent on his admiration, or on being the perpetual object of his attention. She respected his privacy, and never attempted to intrude into those concerns which he thought proper to keep to himself. In short, Mr. and Mrs. Bennet were well matched in understanding, though Mr. Bennet often wondered how such a woman had ever captivated his fancy. Their matrimonial felicity was not of the most brilliant kind, but it was solid and permanent.

es_second_half: de ella era menos difícil, era una mujer de poca inteligencia, más bien inculta y de temperamento desigual. Su meta en la vida era casar a sus hijas; su consuelo, las visitas y el cotilleo.
es_results_raw: misterio y la complejidad de su personalidad lo mantenían constantemente en estado de alerta, siempre listo para desentrañar los matices más sutiles de las interacciones sociales. A pesar de su aparente distanciamiento, Bennet mostraba una curiosidad insaciable por las vidas de los demás, especialmente aquellas que involucraban emociones complejas o situaciones inesperadas. Su sarcasmo era un arma afilada que usaba con precisión para señalar falacias o exageraciones, pero a menudo ocultaba una profunda comprensión y empatía. Caprichoso, prefería el orden personal y se resistía a las expectativas de los demás, lo que a veces le llevaba a comportamientos inesperados. Sin embargo, este carácter inconstante también era su manera de mantener a raya a aquellos que intentaban manipulárselo o entenderlo completamente, manteniendo así su independencia y autenticidad. Reservado, Bennet guardaba sus pensamientos y emociones más profundas para aquellos muy pocos a quienes confiaba, creyendo que la intimidad era algo valioso y cautivador que no debía ser abarrotado casualmente. Su carácter era un mosaico de contrastes, cada uno reflejando una parte distintiva de su personalidad, lo que lo hacía un personaje complejo y fascinante dentro de la narrativa.

en_first_half: “Pride,” observed Mary, who piqued herself upon the solidity of her reflections, “is a very common failing, I believe. By all that I have ever read, I am convinced that it is very common indeed; that human nature is particularly prone to it, and that there are very few of us who do not
en_second_half: cherish a feeling of self-complacency on the score of some quality or other, real or imaginary. Vanity and pride are different things, though the words are often used synonymously. A person may be proud without being vain. Pride relates more to our opinion of ourselves; vanity to what we would have others think of us.”
en_results_raw: fall into its snare at one time or another. It is, in fact, so prevalent that it may be regarded as one of the leading characteristics of our species. We are all, more or less, subject to this weakness; and it is only by a constant vigilance and a conscientious effort to keep our minds free from this besetting sin that we can hope to avoid its pernicious effects. Pride, you see, is a very subtle and insidious vice. It creeps into our thoughts unawares, and before we are aware, it has taken root and begun to flourish. It distorts our judgment, colors our perceptions, and leads us astray. It makes us think more highly of ourselves than we have any right to, and blinds us to our own faults and failings. It breeds contempt for others, and sets us up as superior beings, above the ordinary run of humanity. It is a barrier to humility, charity, and true fellowship. It is a barrier to growth and improvement, for it prevents us from learning from others and from acknowledging our own limitations. It is a barrier to happiness, for it breeds dissatisfaction and discontent. Only by recognizing our own fallibility and striving to overcome our pride can we hope to lead a truly virtuous and fulfilling life. It is a difficult battle, but one that is well worth fighting, for the rewards are immeasurable. In the end, it is not pride that defines us, but our willingness to humble ourselves, to learn, and to grow.

en_second_half: of some delicacy, and requiring early attention. It is from my cousin, Mr. Collins, who, when I am dead, may turn you all out of this house as soon as he pleases.”
en_results_raw: of doing so, as it was a matter of some importance. The writer of the letter, however, has not yet received my answer, and I am informed that he is now on the point of applying to the police. This, as you may imagine, is rather an awkward state of things; and I am anxious to get rid of the matter as soon as possible. I have, therefore, hit upon a plan which I am sure will succeed, and which, if you will assist me, may be carried into effect without the least risk of detection. The writer of the letter is a man of considerable influence in the town, and is well known to the police. If, therefore, I can manage to make him believe that my answer has been lost in the post, he will not dream of troubling the authorities about it. To effect this, I propose to send him a forged letter, apparently from the postmaster, stating that my reply has been delayed, and will arrive shortly. This letter must be so cleverly done that it will pass muster with the writer of the original letter, and I am confident that it can be executed to my satisfaction. Now, I want you to write this letter for me. You have a talent for such work, and I know you can do it well. If you agree, I will pay you handsomely for your trouble."

Bu bağın karmaşıklığı, her iki karakterin kişisel gelişimini ve ilişkilerini daha derinlemesine anlamaya yardımcı olur. Elizabeth ve Charlotte'nin ilişkileri, Jane Austen'un "Pride and Prejudice" romanında önemli bir tema olarak ele alınır ve okuyuculara, aynı zamanda toplumsal normlar ve bireyin kişisel kararlar arasındaki çatışmalar hakkında derinlemesine bir anlayış sunar.

en_first_half: “I have no right to give my opinion,” said Wickham, “as to his being agreeable or otherwise. I am not qualified to form one. I have known him too long and too well to be a fair
en_second_half: judge. It is impossible for me to be impartial. But I believe your opinion of him would in general astonish—and, perhaps, you would not express it quite so strongly anywhere else. Here you are in your own family.”
en_results_raw: judge. My acquaintance with him began when he was a boy of eleven or twelve years old, and continued till he was between seventeen and eighteen. During that time I lived in the family, was in his society constantly, saw his inclinations, his dispositions, his manners, his conduct, his virtues, and his vices. I am convinced, from the whole tenor of his life, that he is the most affectionate, the most faithful, the most sincere friend that a young man can possess. His heart is open, his understanding clear, his judgment sound. He has a remarkable talent for making himself agreeable in society, and a still greater one for being beloved by those who know him. His disposition is gentle and obliging; he has a kindness of heart that is truly admirable, and a generosity that would be remarkable in a person of a much higher rank. His faults, if they may be called faults, are the natural imperfections of a young man of his age and situation. He is sometimes thoughtless, sometimes imprudent, sometimes too much influenced by the suggestions of others; but these are the errors of youth, which time and reflection will gradually remove. In my opinion, Mr. Darcy is exactly the kind of man to make a woman happy, and I am persuaded that any lady who marries him will have reason to prize his affection. His understanding, his connections, and his fortune, are advantages which few can boast of possessing in so high a degree. His manners are elegant, though reserved; and his disposition is decidedly kind and amiable. He may not be the most brilliant or the most captivating man in the world, but there is a solidity and reliability in his character which is highly respectable, and which ensures the happiness of those who are dear to him."

A través de sus errores y sus descubrimientos, creció y se fortaleció, aprendiendo valiosas lecciones sobre confianza en uno mismo y la importancia de no dejarse llevar por la apariencia o las palabras de los demás. He had spoken with a conviction that he believed to be profound, yet his voice trembled slightly, betraying his nervousness. His eyes, however, were fixed with a resolute glare upon Lady Catherine, as if daring her to challenge his resolve. The room fell into a heavy silence, broken only by the soft rustle of the afternoon breeze filtering through the open windows. Lady Catherine, for her part, appeared momentarily taken aback by the unexpected vehemence of Mr. Collins's words. Her usual air of unchallenged authority seemed momentarily shaken, but she quickly regained her composure, her sharp eyes narrowing as she assessed the situation. “Mr. Collins,” she began, her tone still commanding but now laced with a hint of condescension, “I am surprised at your forwardness. It is not for you to dictate terms to Mr. Darcy or to imply that you possess any influence over his actions. Remember your place.” Her words were like a sharp cutlass, aimed to remind him of his inferior status. Yet, Mr. Collins, emboldened perhaps by his recent marriage and the support he believed it had given him, did not immediately cower. Instead, he took a deep breath, his chest expanding with a mixture of fear and misguided confidence. “My lady,” he replied, his voice steadier this time, “I mean no disrespect. It is simply that I am bound by duty and honor to stand up for what I believe is right. If Mr. Darcy's behavior towards Miss Bennet is not in accordance with the principles of respect and propriety, then I must, in good conscience, express my disapproval.” His words, though earnest, carried a faint echo of the awkwardness that was ever-present in his demeanor. Lady Catherine, for her part, seemed momentarily taken aback by the earnestness of his defense, but her expression quickly hardened once more. “We shall see, Mr. Collins,” she replied coolly, her eyes narrowing as she considered the implications of his boldness. “We shall see.” With that, she turned her attention back to the card game, dismissing Mr. Collins as if he were a minor inconvenience, though the gravity of his words had undoubtedly left an impression on her mind. The room slowly returned to its previous state of genteel activity, the tension dissipated, but the undercurrent of change was palpable. Mr. Collins, for his part, sat down once more, his heart pounding with a mixture of fear and exhilaration. He had challenged the formidable Lady Catherine de Bourgh, and though the outcome remained uncertain, he could not help but feel a sense of accomplishment for standing his ground.

They are nouveaux riches, which always seems to invite a certain level of disdain from those who consider themselves part of the old nobility. Elizabeth Bennet, on the other hand, comes from a family that, while not wealthy, possesses a certain genteel status and a long-standing respectability. Her father, though not wealthy, is well-respected in their social circle, and her mother, though somewhat flighty, is still considered a gentlewoman. Elizabeth herself is intelligent, spirited, and independent, qualities that are not always appreciated in a woman of her time. Her wit and sharp tongue can sometimes put her at odds with others, but she is always true to herself. Her relationship with Mr. Darcy, initially fraught with misunderstandings and prejudice, ultimately reveals the depth of his character and the strength of their connection. Their journey from enmity to love is a testament to the power of understanding, humility, and the ability to look beyond one's own preconceptions.

The room, a grand drawing-room in the heart of a stately home, was filled with the murmur of various conversations, the clinking of glasses, and the soft rustle of silk and wool as people shifted in their seats. The atmosphere was one of restrained formality, typical of an upper-class gathering where every word and gesture was scrutinized. Sir William, a man of considerable stature and sharp features, had a reputation for being abrupt and to the point, often cutting off others mid-sentence with his booming voice. His interruption, whether intentional or not, had a way of commanding attention, drawing all eyes to him as he redirected the conversation towards topics of his interest, typically those concerning estate management and the latest news from London. Meanwhile, the two individuals he had supposedly interrupted, a young couple seated somewhat apart from the main cluster of guests, exchanged glances that spoke volumes. The young man, visibly flustered, seemed to be searching for his words, while the young woman, with a composed expression, appeared to be assessing the situation. Their conversation, whatever it had been about, now lay forgotten, overshadowed by the unexpected interruption and the social dynamics of the room.

en_first_half: “You must give me leave to flatter myself, my dear cousin, that your refusal of my addresses are merely words of course. My reasons for believing it are briefly these:—It does not appear to me that my hand is unworthy your acceptance, or that the establishment I can offer would be any other than highly desirable. My situation in life, my connections with the family of De Bourgh, and my relationship to your own, are circumstances highly in my favour; and you should take it
en_second_half: into further consideration that, in spite of your manifold attractions, it is by no means certain that another offer of marriage may ever be made you. Your portion is unhappily so small, that it will in all likelihood undo the effects of your loveliness and amiable qualifications. As I must, therefore, conclude that you are not serious in your rejection of me, I shall choose to attribute it to your wish of increasing my love by suspense, according to the usual practice of elegant females.”

en_first_half: About the middle of the next day, as she was in her room getting ready for a walk, a sudden noise below seemed to speak the whole house in confusion; and, after

The housemaid, breathless and flustered, met her eyes and gasped out that a terrible accident had occurred. The gardener's boy, while tending to the flower beds, had fallen into the pond and was now struggling to stay afloat amidst the lily pads. Without a moment's hesitation, Alice rushed down the stairs, her mind racing with thoughts of how to rescue the boy. She spotted him from a distance, his head bobbing above the water, his face pale and scared. Ignoring the chill of the morning air, she stripped off her jacket and waded into the pond, the water cold and murky around her ankles. Reaching the boy, she grabbed his arm, feeling the shock of the cold water through her gloves. With all her strength, she pulled him towards the edge of the pond, her breath coming in short, panicked gasps. Once he was safely out of the water, she collapsed onto the grass, her body shivering uncontrollably. The gardener's boy coughed and sputtered, grateful beyond words, as Alice checked him over for injuries, her hands trembling but her voice steady as she reassured him that he would be alright. The housekeeper, having rushed out with a blanket, wrapped it around the boy, while Alice sat beside him, her heart still racing from the adrenaline of the rescue. The incident had brought the household together in a way few things ever could, and as the boy was taken inside to warm up and dry off, Alice couldn't help but feel a surge of pride for having acted so quickly and bravely. The morning's walk was forgotten, replaced by the warmth of community and the relief that no harm had come to the young boy.

Su primer pensamiento fue que pudo haber sido un accidente automóvil cercano, pero al abrir la ventana, no vio ninguna de las características típicas de un accidente, como destrozos en el pavimento o vehículos dañados. Decidió entonces que podría haber sido un animal, quizás un perro o un gato, que se había topado con algo. Sin embargo, la persistente confusión y el ruido continuado lo llevaron a salir de casa para investigar de cerca. Al caminar por el vecindario, notó que algunos vecinos salían de sus casas con expresiones de preocupación, lo que le indicaba que el ruido no era algo común. Decidió entonces que debía buscar la fuente del problema de cerca, pero sin dar señales de su presencia, para no asustar a los residentes. Mientras avanzaba cuidadosamente por el calle, observó que el ruido parecía provenir de un árbol cercano, donde un grupo de pájaros parecía estar causando un gran caos al intentar escapar de su nido. Su sorpresa fue grande al darse cuenta de que el ruido era simplemente el sonido de una gran multitud de pájaros que, al despertar, habían comenzado a cazarse entre ellos, creando un caos en el árbol. en_first_half: “You shall hear, then—but prepare for something very dreadful. The first time of my ever seeing him in Hertfordshire, you must know, was at a ball—and at this ball, what do you think he did? He danced only four dances! I am
en_second_half: sorry to pain you, but so it was. He danced only four dances, though gentlemen were scarce; and, to my certain knowledge, more than one young lady was sitting down in want of a partner. Mr. Darcy, you cannot deny the fact.”
en_results_raw: never to be forgotten. I could hardly believe my ears when Mrs. Jennings repeated it to me the next day. Such a slight offense, one might think, but in the eyes of a mother who had spent years dreaming of her son's social success and matrimonial happiness, it was a grave disappointment. Mr. Darcy, with his aloof and seemingly indifferent demeanor, had not only failed to make a good impression but had also, in a way, slighted the very people he should have endeared himself to. The ball was a crucial social event, a place where connections were made, alliances formed, and reputations were either cemented or tarnished. By choosing to dance only four dances, Darcy had not just ignored the expectations of the society he was a part of; he had also missed a significant opportunity to charm and win over the people who could potentially support his future endeavors. This act of apparent disregard for social norms and expectations was not something that could be easily overlooked or forgotten. It was a first impression that set the tone for all that followed, casting a shadow over his character that would take considerable effort to dispel. Mrs. Bennet, in particular, was incensed by this behavior, seeing it as a direct affront to her own social standing and aspirations for her daughters. The incident became a talking point among the neighborhood, with many expressing their shock and disapproval. It was a story that Mrs. Bennet would recount with a mix of indignation and disbelief, each retelling adding a new layer of drama to the already sensational narrative. The four dances became a symbol of Darcy's perceived arrogance and detachment, a reputation that would follow him throughout the countryside and influence the perceptions of those he encountered. It was a misstep that, in the intricate dance of manners and expectations that was Regency society, would have repercussions far beyond the confines of a single ballroom.

His interference was a breach of trust and a violation of personal freedom, qualities that Mr. Darcy, with his pride and prejudice, seemed to overlook in his eagerness to maintain appearances and his own social standing. Elizabeth Bennet, the spirited and independent young woman that she was, could not help but feel indignant at such presumption. She valued her own agency and the right to make her own decisions, especially regarding matters of the heart. Her relationship with Mr. Darcy, though initially fraught with misunderstandings and resentment, ultimately taught both of them the importance of respect, humility, and the recognition of each other's worth beyond social status and wealth. Their journey from enmity to love was a testament to the transformative power of understanding, empathy, and the willingness to change. Elizabeth's character, marked by her intelligence, wit, and moral fortitude, stood as a beacon of strength and independence in a society that often sought to confine women within narrow boundaries. Her refusal to be dictated to by Mr. Darcy or any other man was a bold assertion of her right to self-determination, a principle that resonated deeply with her and shaped the course of her life and relationships. In the end, it was through mutual respect and a deepening appreciation for each other's virtues that Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy found a partnership that was both equitable and deeply fulfilling.

She had become cold and distant, her love replaced by a calculating disdain. Elizabeth often found herself caught in the middle, torn between her duty to her family and her own sense of morality. The respect she once held for his intellect and affection was slowly eroded by the realization that his actions not only betrayed his vows but also brought shame upon their family name. This shame was not just a stain on their reputation but a heavy burden on Elizabeth's shoulders, as she feared the day it would be brought into the public eye, tarnishing her own future prospects. Her father's behaviour was a constant reminder of the fragility of trust and the enduring power of love and duty. Despite her efforts to move past the pain, Elizabeth could not ignore the growing unease within her. She knew that one day, she would have to confront the reality of her father's actions, not just for her own peace of mind but for the sake of her family's honor and her own future. "¿Deberíamos esperar a que se vaya?", preguntó Mark, su voz llena de nerviosismo. "No lo sé", respondió Elizabeth, su mente llena de dudas. "Quizás deberíamos buscar otra manera de entrar o simplemente esperar hasta que se vaya". Mientras discutían sus opciones, un ruido extraño salió de la casa, lo que aumentó aún más su tensión. "¿Fue eso un ruido de puerta?", preguntó Mark, listo para defenderse si fuera necesario. Elizabeth no respondió; estaba demasiado preocupada por las posibles consecuencias de sus próximas decisiones. "Debemos actuar rápido", dijo finalmente. "Pero cómo?", respondió Mark, confundido. "Quizás podemos buscar algo que nos ayude a entrar sin ser detectados", sugirió Elizabeth, intentando mantener la calma. "Podemos ver si hay alguna ventana abierta o si podemos forzar la puerta", continuó, adoptando una actitud decidida. Mientras planificaban su próximo movimiento, el silencio se instaló de nuevo en la escena, solo interrumpido por el sonido de sus respiraciones agitadas y el crujido de la ropa mientras se movían silenciosamente cerca de la morada enojante. La incertidumbre y el peligro flotaban en el aire, pero Elizabeth y Mark estaban decididos a superar esta adversidad, sin importar los riesgos que enfrentaran. "Vamos", murmuró Elizabeth, moviéndose hacia la casa con una mezcla de valentía y miedo. "Tenemos que descubrir lo que está oculto dentro y resolver esto, juntos", agregó, tomando la mano de Mark con firmeza. Juntos, avanzaron hacia el peligro, listos para enfrentar lo que viera venir.

The novelty of the event, the uncertainty of its issue, and the various emotions it excited, were sufficient to banish every thought of weariness, and to keep their minds in a state of continual agitation. The more they reflected on the possible consequences, the more their imaginations were excited, running over a thousand different scenarios, each more improbable than the last. They speculated on the future of their country, the fate of their families, and the uncertain course of their own lives. The discussions were often heated, with friends and foes alike voicing their opinions passionately, yet always with a sense of duty and respect for differing viewpoints. The more they debated, the more they realized how little they truly knew about the broader implications of the event, and how much their understanding of their own world was tied up in its outcome. This perpetual cycle of speculation and discussion, far from diminishing their interest, only served to fuel it further, keeping the topic at the forefront of their minds and conversations.

en_first_half: Mr. Bennet made no answer; and each of them, deep in thought, continued silent till they reached
en_second_half: the house. Their father then went to the library to write, and the girls walked into the breakfast-room.
en_results_raw: Mr. Collins's parish. As they walked on, Elizabeth could not help reflecting on the strangeness of her father's behavior. It was unlike him to remain so reticent, especially in the presence of Mr. Collins, whose obsequious manner was as irritating as it was predictable. She wondered if he was pondering the implications of Charlotte's impending marriage, a union that seemed to Elizabeth both a practical necessity and a personal sacrifice. Meanwhile, Mr. Collins, oblivious to the inner turmoil of his companions, basked in the pleasure of being noticed by a lady of such distinction, his conversation limited to effusive compliments and awkward flattery. The silence between them was a palpable barrier, a reflection of the complex emotions and thoughts swirling within each individual's mind. Elizabeth, usually quick to engage in conversation, found herself at a loss, her usual wit stifled by the weight of the situation. Mr. Bennet, usually quick to offer a cutting remark or a wry observation, seemed to be lost in contemplation, perhaps considering the future of Longbourn and the entail that threatened to alter the course of his family's destiny. The journey to Meryton, usually a mundane errand, had taken on a new significance, laden with the gravity of personal and familial decisions. As they approached the village, the reality of Charlotte's choice and its consequences loomed large, casting a shadow over the otherwise pleasant walk.

Las casas que propones son representativas de diferentes estilos de vida y ambientes, cada uno con sus ventajas y desventajas. La primera casa es más modesta y cómoda, adecuada para quienes prefieren una vida tranquila y sin excesos. Su cocina es pequeña pero funcional, y el espacio exterior permite al aire circulatorio fluir libremente, lo que podría ser ideal para una familia que valora la simplicidad y la comodidad. Por otro lado, la segunda casa es mucho más grande y moderna, con todas las comodidades y tecnología avanzada que podrías imaginar. Tiene espacios abiertos y una gran cocina equipada, perfecta para aquellas familias que disfrutan de una vida activa y desean tener suficiente espacio para organizar eventos y reuniones. La tercera casa, por último, combina elementos de ambas casas anteriores, ofreciendo una solución equilibrada. Tiene una gran cocina con todos los accesorios modernos, pero también conserva un ambiente acogedor y familiar. Su diseño exterior permite tanto privacidad como exposición, lo que podría ser ideal para alguien que busca un equilibrio entre comodidad y estilo. Antes de tomar una decisión, es crucial que reflexione sobre sus prioridades. ¿Qué aspecto más valora? ¿La comodidad y el confort? ¿O quizás la modernidad y el estilo? Cada casa tiene sus fortalezas, y la elección correcta dependerá de lo que considere más importante para su bienestar y felicidad. Recuerde que esta decisión no solo afectará su vida diaria, sino también el de sus hijos y, eventualmente, de sus futuros generaciones. Es un momento decisivo que merece ser tomado con cuidado y reflexión.

Lúc này, một cảnh hài hước xảy ra khi một con chó của một người thân xung quanh đưa đầu vào phòng ăn, nhưng không may mắn nên bị bỏ lại xa. Gia đình Bennet thậm chí còn có một người thân yêu thích khác đang đến, là Mr. Collins, người bạn của tư cách thân thiết và người có ý định kết hôn với một trong các con gái Bennet. Tất cả mọi người mong muốn màn cười của họ có thể truyền cảm hứng cho Mr. Collins khi anh ấy bước vào phòng ăn. Tuy nhiên, một điều nguy hiểm có thể xảy ra là một số người không muốn màn cười của họ trở nên quá nóng, đặc biệt là khi đối mặt với những ý định hôn nhân của Mr. Collins, đóng vai trò như một "đối tượng không mong muốn" trong diễn biến tình cảm của gia đình Bennet.

en_first_half: Mrs. Bennet had been strongly inclined to ask them to stay and dine there that day; but, though she always kept a very good table, she did not think anything less
en_second_half: than two courses could be good enough for a man on whom she had such anxious designs, or satisfy the appetite and pride of one who had ten thousand a year.
en_results_raw: to be suitable for such distinguished guests. She knew that their journey had probably made them hungry, and she was anxious to show her hospitality in the best light. However, Mr. Bennet, with his usual calm and sometimes frustrating practicality, suggested that it might be more convenient for their plans to take a meal at an inn, where they could rest and prepare for their onward journey without the formality and delay of a dinner at their home. This practical suggestion, though perhaps lacking in the warmth of a personal invitation, was likely to be the more agreeable option for the travelers who might appreciate a quiet, efficient meal without the fuss of a formal dinner. Mrs. Bennet, though disappointed, had to acknowledge the wisdom in Mr. Bennet's words, and so she gracefully agreed, suggesting they meet again under more suitable circumstances to enjoy her hospitality at its best.
